entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, ultimately from Latin dactylus dactyl

def.dt: :the oblong edible fruit of a palm (Phoenix dactylifera)
:the tall palm with pinnate leaves that yields the date

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Late Latin data, from data (as in data Romae given at Rome), feminine of Latin datus, past participle of dare to give; akin to Latin dos gift, dowry, Greek didonai to give

def.dt: :the time at which an event occurs the date of his birth
:a statement of the time of execution or making the date on the letter
:duration
:the period of time to which something belongs
:an appointment to meet at a specified time
:a social engagement between two persons that often has a romantic character
:a person with whom one has a usually romantic date
:an engagement for a professional performance (as of a dance band)
:up to the present moment
:to determine the date of date an antique
:to record the date of :mark with the date
:to mark with characteristics typical of a particular period
:to show up plainly the age of
:to make or have a date with
:to reckon chronologically
:originate a friendship dating from college days
:to become dated
:to go out on usually romantic dates
:rape committed by the victim's date
:acquaintance rape
:to commit date rape on
:a drug (as GHB) administered surreptitiously (as in a drink) to induce an unconscious or sedated state in a potential date rape victim
:a date between two persons who have not previously met
:either participant in a blind date
:a date participated in by two couples
:the date after which something (as a credit card) is no longer in effect
:the date after which a product (as food or medicine) should not be sold because of an expected decline in quality or effectiveness
:an arbitrary line approximately along the 180th meridian designated as the place where each calendar day begins
